collection_name: AIBE Previous Years Questions Bank (XVII, XVIII, XIX)
description: Authentic previous year AIBE questions with detailed explanations and section references

questions.subject: Constitutional Law
questions.question: The concept of freedom of trade and commerce mentioned in the Indian Constitution is motivated from the experience of which country?
questions.explanation: Articles 301-307 of the Indian Constitution deal with freedom of trade and commerce. This concept was borrowed from the Australian Constitution, which had provisions for free interstate trade and commerce to create a common market.

questions.subject: Constitutional Law
questions.question: Which of the following writ is issued to enforce the performance of public duties by the authority?
questions.explanation: Mandamus (meaning 'we command') is issued by a higher court to a lower court or public authority to compel performance of a public duty which has been refused or neglected. Article 32 and 226 empower courts to issue writs including Mandamus.

questions.subject: Constitutional Law
questions.question: Which Constitutional Amendment Act had made the provision for publishing Hindi Translation of the Constitution?
questions.explanation: The 58th Constitutional Amendment Act, 1987 authorized the publication of the Constitution in Hindi. Article 394A provides for authoritative text in Hindi.

questions.subject: Constitutional Law
questions.question: Which provision of the Constitution of India is relevant for solving questions of repugnancy between a Central law and a State law?
questions.explanation: Article 254 deals with inconsistency between laws made by Parliament and laws made by State Legislatures. If there's repugnancy, the Central law prevails unless the State law has received Presidential assent.

questions.subject: Criminal Law - IPC
questions.question: What punishment is prescribed under the Indian Penal Code, 1860 for a person who maims any minor in order that such minor may be used for the purposes of begging?
options: Imprisonment up to 5 years and fine
Imprisonment up to 7 years and fine
Imprisonment up to 10 years and fine
questions.explanation: Section 363A IPC prescribes punishment for kidnapping or maiming a minor for purposes of begging. The punishment is imprisonment which may extend to 10 years and also liable to fine.

questions.subject: Criminal Law - IPC
questions.question: X threatens to publish a defamatory libel concerning Y unless Y gives him money. Which punishment may be given to X for the act committed by him as per the Indian Penal Code, 1860?
options: Imprisonment up to 2 years, or with fine or with both
Imprisonment up to 3 years, or with fine or with both
Imprisonment up to 5 years, or with fine or with both
Imprisonment up to 7 years, or with fine or with both
questions.explanation: This constitutes criminal intimidation under Section 503 IPC. When the threat is to cause injury to reputation, Section 506 prescribes imprisonment up to 2 years or fine or both.

questions.subject: Criminal Procedure Code
questions.question: Which of the following sentence is an Assistant Sessions Judge authorised to pass as per the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973?
questions.explanation: Section 28 of CrPC limits the sentencing powers of Assistant Sessions Judge. They can pass any sentence except a sentence of death or of imprisonment for life or of imprisonment for a term exceeding 10 years.

questions.subject: Intellectual Property Law
questions.question: What is the term of copyright protection for an original literary work under Indian Copyright Act?
questions.explanation: Section 22 of the Copyright Act, 1957 provides that copyright in literary, dramatic, musical and artistic works subsists for 60 years from the year following the death of the author (life of author plus 60 years).

questions.subject: Alternative Dispute Resolution
questions.question: Which of the following is a key advantage of arbitration over litigation?
options: It is generally faster than litigation
It always results in a binding decision
It is mandatory for all disputes
questions.explanation: Arbitration under the Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996 is generally faster, more confidential, and flexible compared to traditional court litigation. Parties can choose arbitrators with relevant expertise.

questions.subject: Information Technology Law
questions.question: Phishing is punishable under which provision?
questions.explanation: Section 66D of the Information Technology Act, 2000 specifically deals with punishment for cheating by personation using computer resources (phishing). Punishment is imprisonment up to 3 years and fine up to 1 lakh.

questions.subject: Contract Law
questions.question: According to the Indian Contract Act, 1872, a contract with a minor is:
questions.explanation: As per Mohori Bibee v. Dharmodas Ghose case and Section 11 of Indian Contract Act, a minor is not competent to contract. Hence, any agreement with a minor is void ab initio (void from the beginning).

questions.subject: Contract Law
questions.question: Under which section is 'consideration' defined in the Indian Contract Act, 1872?
questions.explanation: Section 2(d) of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 defines 'consideration' as: 'When at the desire of the promisor, the promisee or any other person has done or abstained from doing, or does or abstains from doing, or promises to do or to abstain from doing, something, such act or abstinence or promise is called a consideration for the promise.'

questions.subject: Family Law
questions.question: Under the Hindu Marriage Act, 1955, which ground is NOT available for divorce by mutual consent?
questions.explanation: Section 13B of Hindu Marriage Act provides for divorce by mutual consent when parties have been living separately for one year and unable to live together. Cruelty is a ground for contested divorce under Section 13(1) but not for mutual consent divorce.

questions.subject: Family Law
questions.question: What is the minimum period of separation required before filing for divorce by mutual consent under Hindu Marriage Act?
questions.explanation: Section 13B of the Hindu Marriage Act, 1955 requires that the parties must have been living separately for a period of one year or more before presenting a petition for divorce by mutual consent.

questions.subject: Property Law
questions.question: Under the Transfer of Property Act, a sale of immovable property of value exceeding Rs. 100 must be:
questions.explanation: Section 54 of the Transfer of Property Act, 1882 mandates that sale of immovable property of the value of one hundred rupees and upwards can only be made by a registered instrument.

questions.subject: Property Law
questions.question: The doctrine of 'lis pendens' is embodied in which section of TPA?
questions.explanation: Section 52 of TPA deals with doctrine of lis pendens (pending litigation). It provides that during the pendency of any suit relating to property, neither party can transfer or deal with the property so as to affect the rights of the other party.

questions.subject: Labour Law
questions.question: Under Industrial Disputes Act, what is the notice period for retrenchment?
questions.explanation: Section 25F of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 requires that one month's notice in writing indicating the reasons for retrenchment must be given to the workman or payment in lieu of notice must be made.

questions.subject: Labour Law
questions.question: Retrenchment compensation under Industrial Disputes Act is calculated at:
options: 15 days average pay for every completed year of service
30 days average pay for every completed year of service
One month salary for every completed year
questions.explanation: Section 25F(b) of Industrial Disputes Act provides that compensation equivalent to fifteen days' average pay for every completed year of continuous service or any part thereof in excess of six months must be paid at the time of retrenchment.

questions.subject: Company Law
questions.question: Minimum number of directors required in a private limited company under Companies Act, 2013:
questions.explanation: Section 149 of the Companies Act, 2013 mandates that every company shall have a minimum of 2 directors in case of a private company and 3 directors in case of a public company. One Person Company (OPC) can have just one director.

questions.subject: Company Law
questions.question: The doctrine of 'ultra vires' means:
questions.explanation: The doctrine of ultra vires (beyond the powers) means that if a company does any act or enters into any contract beyond the powers conferred by the Memorandum of Association or the Companies Act, such act or contract is void and not binding on the company. Established in Ashbury Railway v. Riche.
questions.case_law: Ashbury Railway Carriage Co. v. Riche

questions.subject: Professional Ethics
questions.question: An advocate can be suspended from practice by:
questions.explanation: Section 35 of the Advocates Act, 1961 empowers the State Bar Council to punish an advocate for professional or other misconduct, including suspension of right to practice. Appeals lie to the Bar Council of India.

questions.subject: Professional Ethics
questions.question: According to BCI Rules, can an advocate directly solicit work?
questions.explanation: Rule 36 of the Bar Council of India Rules prohibits soliciting work or advertising. An advocate shall not solicit work or advertise, either directly or indirectly. This is considered professional misconduct.

questions.subject: Civil Procedure Code
questions.question: Under Order VII Rule 11 of CPC, plaint can be rejected on which ground?
questions.explanation: Order VII Rule 11 CPC provides multiple grounds for rejection of plaint including: (a) non-disclosure of cause of action, (b) undervaluation for court fee, (c) claim barred by law, (d) suit appears barred by limitation, (e) not properly valued.

questions.subject: Civil Procedure Code
questions.question: Written statement must be filed within how many days as per CPC?
questions.explanation: Order VIII Rule 1 CPC (amended in 2002) mandates that defendant must file written statement within 30 days from date of service of summons. Court may extend this period up to maximum 90 days for sufficient cause, but not beyond.

questions.subject: Evidence Act
questions.question: Confession made to a police officer is:
questions.explanation: Section 25 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 clearly states that no confession made to a police officer shall be proved as against a person accused of any offence. This is to prevent torture and coercion.

questions.subject: Evidence Act
questions.question: Dying declaration is covered under which section of Evidence Act?
questions.explanation: Section 32(1) of the Indian Evidence Act deals with statements made by a person as to the cause of his death or as to any circumstances of the transaction which resulted in his death (dying declaration). It's an exception to hearsay rule.

questions.subject: Evidence Act
questions.question: Burden of proof lies on:
questions.explanation: Section 101 of Evidence Act provides that whoever desires any court to give judgment as to any legal right or liability dependent on the existence of facts which he asserts must prove that those facts exist. The burden of proof lies on the person who asserts, not who denies.

questions.subject: Torts
questions.question: The principle 'Res ipsa loquitur' means:
questions.explanation: Res ipsa loquitur (the thing speaks for itself) is a doctrine in tort law that applies when the circumstances of an accident imply negligence. Used when the nature of the accident is such that it would not have occurred without negligence.

questions.subject: Torts
questions.question: Absolute liability was established in which landmark case?
options: M.C. Mehta v. Union of India
questions.explanation: The doctrine of Absolute Liability was established by the Supreme Court of India in M.C. Mehta v. Union of India (Oleum Gas Leak Case, 1987). It's stricter than the rule in Rylands v. Fletcher and has no exceptions.
questions.case_law: M.C. Mehta v. Union of India (1987)

questions.subject: Administrative Law
questions.question: Natural justice requires:
options: Right to be heard (audi alteram partem)
No bias rule (nemo judex in causa sua)
questions.explanation: The two fundamental principles of natural justice are: (1) Audi alteram partem - right to be heard, no one should be condemned unheard, and (2) Nemo judex in causa sua - no one should be a judge in his own cause, rule against bias.

questions.subject: Jurisprudence
questions.question: Who is known as the father of International Law?
questions.explanation: Hugo Grotius (1583-1645) is regarded as the father of International Law. His work 'De Jure Belli ac Pacis' (On the Law of War and Peace) laid the foundation for international law based on natural law.

questions.subject: Jurisprudence
questions.question: According to Salmond, law is:
options: Body of principles recognized and applied by the state
questions.explanation: John Salmond defined law as 'the body of principles recognized and applied by the state in the administration of justice.' He emphasized that law consists of rules recognized and acted upon by courts of justice.

questions.subject: Criminal Law - IPC
questions.question: Section 34 IPC deals with:
questions.explanation: Section 34 IPC deals with 'Acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention.' When a criminal act is done by several persons in furtherance of the common intention of all, each is liable as if done by him alone.

questions.subject: Criminal Law - IPC
questions.question: Murder is defined under which section of IPC?
questions.explanation: Section 300 IPC defines 'Murder' as culpable homicide with specific intent or circumstances. Section 299 defines culpable homicide, Section 302 prescribes punishment for murder, and Section 304 deals with culpable homicide not amounting to murder.

questions.subject: Criminal Procedure Code
questions.question: FIR is registered under which section of CrPC?
questions.explanation: Section 154 CrPC deals with 'Information in cognizable cases.' Every information relating to commission of a cognizable offence must be reduced to writing by the police officer in charge of the police station, which becomes the First Information Report (FIR).

questions.subject: Criminal Procedure Code
questions.question: Anticipatory bail is provided under:
questions.explanation: Section 438 CrPC provides for 'Direction for grant of bail to person apprehending arrest' commonly known as anticipatory bail. High Court or Court of Session can grant this when a person has reason to believe he may be arrested for a non-bailable offence.

questions.subject: Criminal Procedure Code
questions.question: Police can detain a person without producing before Magistrate for maximum:
questions.explanation: Section 57 CrPC mandates that a police officer making an arrest without warrant must produce the arrested person before a Magistrate within 24 hours of arrest, excluding the time necessary for journey from the place of arrest to the Magistrate's court.

questions.subject: Constitutional Law
questions.question: Article 21 of the Constitution guarantees:
options: Right to life and personal liberty
questions.explanation: Article 21 provides that 'No person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law.' This has been given expansive interpretation including right to live with dignity, right to livelihood, right to health, etc.
questions.case_law: Maneka Gandhi v. Union of India

questions.subject: Constitutional Law
questions.question: Basic Structure doctrine was established in:
options: Kesavananda Bharati v. State of Kerala
Minerva Mills v. Union of India
Indira Nehru Gandhi v. Raj Narain
questions.explanation: The Basic Structure doctrine was laid down by the Supreme Court in Kesavananda Bharati v. State of Kerala (1973). It held that Parliament cannot amend the Constitution to destroy its basic structure. Features like federalism, secularism, democracy are part of basic structure.
questions.case_law: Kesavananda Bharati v. State of Kerala (1973)

questions.subject: Constitutional Law
questions.question: Fundamental Duties are contained in:
questions.explanation: Fundamental Duties are contained in Part IVA of the Constitution (Article 51A). They were added by the 42nd Constitutional Amendment Act, 1976 on the recommendation of Swaran Singh Committee. Originally 10 duties, now 11 (11th added by 86th Amendment).

questions.subject: Contract Law
questions.question: According to Section 10, a valid contract requires:
questions.explanation: Section 10 of Indian Contract Act states: 'All agreements are contracts if they are made by free consent of parties competent to contract, for a lawful consideration and with a lawful object, and are not hereby expressly declared to be void.'

questions.subject: Contract Law
questions.question: Doctrine of frustration is covered under:
questions.explanation: Section 56 of Indian Contract Act deals with 'Agreement to do impossible act' and doctrine of frustration. When contract becomes impossible to perform or unlawful after formation due to supervening impossibility, it becomes void.

questions.subject: Contract Law
questions.question: Quantum meruit means:
questions.explanation: Quantum meruit literally means 'as much as earned' or 'in proportion to work done.' It's a quasi-contractual remedy where one party can claim reasonable remuneration for work done or services rendered when the contract is discharged.

questions.subject: Property Law
questions.question: How many types of mortgages are recognized under TPA?
questions.explanation: Section 58 of TPA recognizes six types of mortgages: (1) Simple mortgage, (2) Mortgage by conditional sale, (3) Usufructuary mortgage, (4) English mortgage, (5) Mortgage by deposit of title deeds (Equitable mortgage), (6) Anomalous mortgage.

questions.subject: Property Law
questions.question: Doctrine of part performance is under:
questions.explanation: Section 53A of TPA deals with part performance of contract. It provides that when a person contracts to transfer immovable property for consideration, and the transferee has taken possession and performed part of his obligation, the transferor cannot enforce right of transfer adverse to the contract.

questions.subject: Family Law - Hindu
questions.question: Coparcenary under Hindu law means:
questions.explanation: Coparcenary is a narrower body within joint family consisting of persons who acquire by birth an interest in joint family/ancestral property. Hindu Succession (Amendment) Act, 2005 made daughters coparceners by birth with equal rights as sons.

questions.subject: Family Law - Muslim
questions.question: Dower (Mehr) in Muslim law is:
questions.explanation: Dower (Mehr/Mahr) is the sum of money or other property which the wife is entitled to receive from the husband in consideration of the marriage. It's an obligation imposed upon husband as mark of respect for wife.

questions.subject: Family Law - Muslim
questions.question: Iddat period after divorce is generally:
options: Three months or three menstrual cycles
questions.explanation: Iddat is the waiting period a woman must observe after dissolution of marriage. For divorce, it's generally three menstrual courses (quroos) or three lunar months if not menstruating. For death of husband, it's 4 months 10 days.

questions.subject: Labour Law
questions.question: Trade Unions Act was enacted in:
questions.explanation: The Trade Unions Act, 1926 provides for registration of trade unions and immunities for registered trade unions from civil and criminal liabilities in certain cases. It aims to regulate employer-employee relations.

questions.subject: Labour Law
questions.question: Factories Act regulates working conditions in factories and was enacted in:
questions.explanation: The Factories Act, 1948 regulates working conditions in factories regarding health, safety, welfare, working hours, employment of young persons, and annual leave of workers. It defines 'factory' under Section 2(m).

questions.subject: Arbitration
questions.question: Arbitration and Conciliation Act was enacted in:
questions.explanation: The Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996 (effective from 1996, based on UNCITRAL Model Law) consolidated laws relating to domestic and international arbitration, enforcement of foreign awards, and conciliation.

questions.subject: Arbitration
questions.question: Time limit to set aside arbitral award under Section 34 is:
questions.explanation: Section 34(3) of Arbitration Act provides that application for setting aside arbitral award must be made within 3 months from the date of receipt of award. Court may extend this period by another 30 days (but not beyond) if satisfied sufficient cause.

questions.subject: Arbitration
questions.question: Kompetenz-kompetenz principle means:
options: Tribunal can rule on own jurisdiction
questions.explanation: Section 16 of Arbitration Act embodies kompetenz-kompetenz principle - arbitral tribunal may rule on its own jurisdiction including ruling on any objections with respect to the existence or validity of the arbitration agreement.

questions.subject: Company Law
questions.question: MOA and AOA stand for:
options: Memorandum of Association and Articles of Association
Minutes of Association and Articles of Association
Memorandum of Agreement and Articles of Agreement
Minutes of Agreement and Articles of Agreement
questions.explanation: MOA (Memorandum of Association) is the charter/constitution defining scope of company's activities and its relationship with outside world. AOA (Articles of Association) contains internal regulations and management rules of the company.

questions.subject: Company Law
questions.question: One Person Company (OPC) was introduced by:
questions.explanation: The concept of One Person Company (OPC) was introduced for the first time in India by the Companies Act, 2013. OPC can be formed by a single person and requires only one director and one nominee.

questions.subject: Company Law
questions.question: CSR provisions apply to companies with networth of:
questions.explanation: Section 135 of Companies Act mandates CSR (Corporate Social Responsibility) for companies having: (a) networth of Rs. 500 crore or more, OR (b) turnover of Rs. 1000 crore or more, OR (c) net profit of Rs. 5 crore or more. Must spend 2% of average net profits.

questions.subject: Professional Ethics
questions.question: Advocates Act was enacted in:
questions.explanation: The Advocates Act, 1961 regulates the legal profession in India. It provides for constitution of Bar Council of India and State Bar Councils, enrollment of advocates, their rights, privileges and obligations, and disciplinary proceedings.

questions.subject: Professional Ethics
questions.question: Attorney-client privilege is protected under:
questions.explanation: Section 126 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 provides privilege to communications between advocate and client. No advocate shall be permitted/compelled to disclose any communication made to him by his client, unless client himself waives the privilege.

questions.subject: Professional Ethics
questions.question: Bar Council of India was established under:
questions.explanation: Section 4 of the Advocates Act, 1961 provides for constitution of Bar Council of India. BCI is the apex regulatory body for legal profession, performing functions like laying down standards of professional conduct, promoting legal education, etc.

questions.subject: Civil Procedure Code
questions.question: Res judicata is embodied in:
questions.explanation: Section 11 CPC deals with res judicata (matter already adjudicated). Once a matter is finally decided by a competent court, no party can re-agitate the same matter in a subsequent litigation. Promotes finality and prevents multiplicity of suits.

questions.subject: Civil Procedure Code
questions.question: Inherent powers of court are under:
questions.explanation: Section 151 CPC provides inherent powers to courts to make such orders as necessary for the ends of justice or to prevent abuse of process of court. These powers are in addition to powers specifically conferred by CPC.

questions.subject: Civil Procedure Code
questions.question: Summary suit procedure is provided under:
questions.explanation: Order XXXVII CPC provides for summary procedure for recovery of liquidated demands based on written contract, guarantee, or on enactment or government promissory notes. It enables speedy disposal of commercial disputes.

questions.subject: Evidence Act
questions.question: Leading questions are allowed in:
questions.explanation: Section 142 of Evidence Act defines leading questions (questions suggesting the answer). Section 143 allows leading questions in cross-examination. Generally not allowed in examination-in-chief except in introductory matters or undisputed facts.

questions.subject: Evidence Act
questions.question: Judicial notice means:
options: Facts court takes as proved without evidence
questions.explanation: Sections 56-57 of Evidence Act deal with judicial notice. Court takes judicial notice of certain facts without requiring formal proof - like laws in force in India, public holidays, historical facts, etc. Saves time and expense.

questions.subject: Evidence Act
questions.question: Standard of proof in criminal cases is:
questions.explanation: In criminal cases, prosecution must prove guilt 'beyond reasonable doubt' - a very high standard. In civil cases, standard is 'preponderance of probability' or 'balance of probability' - a lower standard than criminal cases.

questions.subject: Criminal Law - IPC
questions.question: Private defense extends to causing death for:
questions.explanation: Section 100 IPC enumerates situations when right of private defense extends to causing death: assault causing reasonable apprehension of death/grievous hurt, rape, acid attack, kidnapping/abduction, wrongful confinement with apprehension of being unable to seek protection.

questions.subject: Criminal Law - IPC
questions.question: Common object is dealt with under:
questions.explanation: Section 149 IPC deals with unlawful assembly with common object. Every member of unlawful assembly guilty of offence committed in prosecution of common object. Different from Section 34 (common intention) - common object need not be pre-planned.

questions.subject: Criminal Procedure Code
questions.question: Plea bargaining is provided under:
questions.explanation: Chapter XXI-A (Sections 265A to 265L) of CrPC, inserted by Criminal Law Amendment Act 2005, provides for plea bargaining. It's a pre-trial negotiation where accused pleads guilty in exchange for lesser sentence. Not available for serious offenses.

questions.subject: Juvenile Justice
questions.question: Juvenile Justice Act defines child as person below:
questions.explanation: The Juvenile Justice (Care and Protection of Children) Act, 2015 defines 'child' as a person who has not completed 18 years of age. It differentiates between 'child in conflict with law' and 'child in need of care and protection'.

questions.subject: Constitutional Law
questions.question: Money Bill can be introduced only in:
questions.explanation: Article 110 defines Money Bill. Article 109 provides that Money Bill can be introduced only in Lok Sabha. Rajya Sabha can only recommend amendments within 14 days which Lok Sabha may accept or reject. Lok Sabha has final say.

questions.subject: Constitutional Law
questions.question: President's rule is imposed under:
questions.explanation: Article 356 provides for President's rule (State Emergency) if President is satisfied that government of State cannot be carried on in accordance with Constitution. State government is suspended and State comes under direct rule of Centre through Governor.

questions.subject: Constitutional Law
questions.question: Directive Principles of State Policy are contained in:
questions.explanation: Part IV (Articles 36-51) contains Directive Principles of State Policy (DPSP). These are guidelines/principles given to State for governance. Not justiciable but fundamental in governance. Complement Fundamental Rights.

questions.subject: Constitutional Law
questions.question: Constitutional amendment requires (generally):
questions.explanation: Article 368 provides for constitutional amendment. Procedure varies: (1) Simple majority for some provisions, (2) Special majority (majority of total membership + 2/3rd of present and voting) for most, (3) Special majority + ratification by half the states for certain provisions.

questions.subject: Torts
questions.question: Vicarious liability means:
questions.explanation: Vicarious liability is liability of one person for wrongful acts of another, though he has not committed the act himself. Common example: employer liable for torts of employee committed in course of employment. Based on principle of respondeat superior (let the master answer).

questions.subject: Torts
questions.question: Injuria sine damno means:
questions.explanation: Injuria sine damno - violation of legal right without any substantial damage. Such infringement is actionable and plaintiff can sue for nominal damages. Example: Ashby v. White - right to vote was infringed though no pecuniary loss. Contrast: damnum sine injuria.

preparation_tips: Focus on Constitution (10 Qs), IPC (8 Qs), CrPC (10 Qs) - these are high-weightage topics
Memorize section numbers - questions directly ask 'Under which section...'
Learn landmark case laws with proper citation
Practice with bare acts as they are allowed in exam
Focus on Professional Ethics - often overlooked but easy marks
Time management: 2 minutes per question average
Don't leave questions unanswered (no negative marking)
Mark difficult questions and return to them later
Read questions carefully - many are tricky with similar options
